message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a mutation on the FMR1 gene. Southern blot with DNA probes is the recommended test to diagnose the mutation. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis is used to separate proteins, PCR followed by northern blot is to study RNA expression, and Western blot is used to study protein expression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The multiple features that the patient exhibits suggest that he may have Fragile X syndrome, which is a genetic condition caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene. Southern blot with DNA probes is the most specific test to diagnose Fragile X syndrome as it can detect changes in the gene's DNA sequence. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis is a method to separate and identify proteins, PCR followed by northern blot with DNA probes is used to detect RNA sequences, and Western blot is used to detect specific proteins in a sample. These tests are not relevant to the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome. Southern blot with DNA probes is the appropriate screening test for Fragile X syndrome, as it detects the expansion of a trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene, which is the cause of the disorder. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and western blot are not related to DNA analysis, and PCR followed by northern blot is not the appropriate test for Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings of the patient suggests he may have Fragile X syndrome, a genetic disorder. Southern blot with DNA probes can detect the expanded CGG repeat on the FMR1 gene, which is the pathognomonic genetic abnormality in Fragile X syndrome. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, PCR followed by northern blot with DNA probes, and western blot are not appropriate tests for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the patient suggest a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. Southern blot analysis is the most appropriate method to detect the repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis is used for protein analysis, PCR followed by northern blotting is used for RNA analysis, and western blotting is used for protein detection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. Southern blot with DNA probes is a standard diagnostic test for detecting the mutation in affected individuals. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and western blot are not relevant to this diagnosis, and PCR followed by northern blot is not a standard diagnostic test for Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy has symptoms of Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene located on the X chromosome. Southern blot with DNA probes is a diagnostic test used to detect the expansion of the CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene that causes Fragile X syndrome. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, PCR followed by northern blot with DNA probes, and Western blot are not appropriate tests for the diagnosis of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s symptoms are consistent with Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene. The diagnostic test of choice is Southern blot analysis with DNA probes to detect the presence of a full mutation or a premutation in the FMR1 gene. The other options are not relevant or applicable for the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome.
